channel.title: Ars-Technica on Panz3r News
channel.description: Recent content in Ars-Technica on news.panz3r.dev

item.title: FDA authorizes use of a nonprescription home COVID test
item.description: Test works with a cellphone app that can alert local health authorities.

item.title: FDA releases data on Moderna’s COVID vaccine: It looks good [Updated]
item.description: Data drop comes ahead of a potential Emergency Use Authorization on Thursday.

item.title: Uber defends sexual assault victims’ privacy, gets fined $59 million
item.description: Victim rights group RAINN said Calif. request risks “re-traumatization of victims.”

item.title: Apple’s watchOS 7.2 is out, offers new health and fitness metrics
item.description: Apple’s health-monitoring claims go far beyond those from typical fitness gear.

item.title: iPhone factory workers say they haven’t been paid, cause millions in damages
item.description: Dramatic video shows employees smashing windows in response to pay disputes.

item.title: The Super-est SuperFX: An unmodified SNES, revved up with ray tracing [Updated]
item.description: FPGA board adds real-time RT effects, “sticks to the broad spirit of ’90s technology.”

item.title: Alan Tudyk plays a crime-solving alien in disguise in Resident Alien trailer
item.description: Syfy series is adapted from the Dark Horse comics by Peter Hogan and Steve Parkhouse.

item.title: The Orion spacecraft is now 15 years old and has flown into space just once
item.description: It was supposed to be the beginning of the Mars era.

item.title: Senator tries to block Frontier’s FCC funding, citing ISP’s various failures
item.description: Senator: Frontier mismanaged previous funds and shouldn’t get new gigabit money.

item.title: Canada set to raise carbon price considerably over next decade
item.description: Plan extends price trajectory to CAN$170 per ton by 2030.

item.title: CDPR admits it “ignored the signals” of Cyberpunk 2077’s console issues
item.description: Refund requests are dependent on console/retailer policies, CDPR says.

item.title: Pinterest agrees to $22.5 million settlement in discrimination lawsuit
item.description: Settlement is one of the largest ever in this kind of case, Brougher’s lawyer said.

item.title: The Google Home Max is dead—Google shuts down production
item.description: The Home Max was $400. It weighed 12 pounds. It was probably too expensive.

item.title: Modern Vintage Gamer talks dev details and hardware hackery
item.description: Maker, breaker, emulator co-developer, YouTuber—MVG’s been around the block.

item.title: EU warns that it may break up Big Tech companies
item.description: Repeat offenses under new rules will trigger action to force divestments.

item.title: The Audi R8 V10 performance: They won’t make them like this much longer
item.description: A mild midlife facelift does nothing to dampen our enthusiasm for the R8.

item.title: SolarWinds hackers have a clever way to bypass multi-factor authentication
item.description: Hackers who hit SolarWinds compromised a think tank three separate times.

item.title: Twenty years later, Dungeons & Dragons gets another movie adaptation
item.description: Co-director clinches a Freaks � Geeks full-circle conclusion.

item.title: FTC kicks off sweeping privacy probe of nine major social media firms
item.description: Consumer privacy has fallen into the FTC’s purview, so it’s digging deep.

item.title: SpaceX won “rural” FCC funding in surprising places, like major airports
item.description: Starlink and other ISPs took advantage of broken FCC system, researcher says.
